Version Control
Semi-automated system for tracking changes with unlimited ‚Äúundo‚Äù

Why Learn Version Control?

Track development of research projects like a lab notebook
Keep project in sync across computers including HPC
Share and collaborate on projects in a clear and manageable way

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
What is Reproducibility & Why?
Reproducibility is...


I want my work to be reproducible because...

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text: By The Turing Way Community

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
The Whole Picture






A (usually fiction) story:


You read a great paper and think ‚ÄúI bet I could apply their analysis methods to my work!‚Äù You click a DOI link in their Data Availability section that they definitely have. It opens to a web page where you can download a folder with R code, data, and documentation about the code and data. The page also has detailed information about how to cite the code and data. You open the folder in R Studio and you are prompted to install all the packages you need to run the code. You open the analysis code script and hit ‚Äúrun‚Äù. All the code runs perfectly with no errors, creating all the figures, tables, and statistics used in the paper. You scroll through the well-formatted R code and understand from the authors‚Äô comments exactly what the code does and how to adapt it to your work.




We want to help you make this story a reality for someone else!

Including future you!

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Syllabus & Workshop Materials
Workshop series website:
https://cct-datascience.github.io/repro-data-sci/

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Screen Setup  

Dual monitors will be very helpful
Virtual desktops (‚ÄúSpaces‚Äù in macOS) also helpful
Let us know if you do not have access to a second monitor

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
section: Creating a Research Compendium with R
text:
Creating a Research Compendium with R
Learning Objectives:

Use RStudio projects to create self-contained reproducible projects
Use best practices for organizing files in a project
Use relative file paths to improve portability of projects
Structure R scripts so they are easier to understand

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Settings for Success










Fresh start ensures reproducibility
Use Session > Restart R to check reproducibility
If long-running code is a concern, there are better solutions

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Research Compendium Best Practices


Treat data as read-only
Use scripts to ‚Äúclean‚Äù and wrangle data
Treat generated outputs as disposable
Put data, code, and outputs in different folders

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Takeaways


Structure files in self-contained projects or ‚Äúresearch compendia‚Äù
Put data in a separate folder and never edit raw data!
Avoid setwd() and getwd()‚Äîuse relative paths and RStudio projects instead
Naming things well is difficult but worth spending time on
Use some consistent style in your code and organize scripts in sections
Split long scripts into multiples and use source() to run them if needed‚Äô

title: Reproducibility & Data Science in R
text:
Homework (optional)
Re-organize an existing project into a research compendium
OR
Apply a consistent coding style to one of your R scripts (e.g.¬†with Code > Reformat Code or with the styler package)



Reproduciblity & Data Science in R

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
README
README.md is the landing page for your GitHub repo, and the first place to look for help understanding it.


Brief project summary
Project status (just an experiment, WIP, archived?)
How to give credit (e.g.¬†if it is associated with a published paper)
Structure of repo (which files do what?)
Instructions on how to reproduce results

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
Markdown
Markdown is a ‚Äúmarkup language‚Äù that let‚Äôs you write plain text to indicate formatting. For example:

**bold text** becomes bold text
~~strikethrough~~ becomes strikethrough
$E = mc^2$ becomes \(E = mc^2\)
[link](https://www.google.com) becomes link
`code()` becomes code()

Check Help > Markdown quick reference in RStudio

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
README.md






Exercise


Edit README.md using some of the markdown tips from the RStudio markdown quick reference

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
Common markdown pitfalls
Spaces between elements matter! How would you fix each of these?
###Heading 3
###Heading 3

Colors:
- red
- green
Colors: - red - green


1.Number one
2.Number two
1.Number one 2.Number two

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
Common markdown pitfalls
Spaces within elements don‚Äôt matter!
This     sentence still  gets    rendered  correctly!
This sentence still gets rendered correctly!
Single line breaks don't separate paragraphs.
See?

You need two line breaks for that!
Single line breaks don‚Äôt separate paragraphs. See?
You need two line breaks for that!

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
What is Quarto?
‚ÄúAn open-source scientific and technical publishing system‚Äù


Mix markdown, code, and the output of code
Produce beautifully formatted documents in a variety of formats (html, Word, pdf, etc.)
Data analysis notebook
Presentations for collaborators
Reproducible manuscripts
‚Ä¶and more!

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
How does Quarto work?

Command line tool, not an R package, but works well with RStudio



knitr or jupyter are used to convert code chunks into markdown, pandoc converts markdown into output

title: Documentation & Literate Programming
text:
Anatomy of a .Qmd file


myreport.qmd

---
title: "My Report"
author: "Eric Scott"
format: 
  html:
    toc: true
---

```{r}
#| label: load-packages
#| include: false

library(tidyverse)
library(gapminder)
```

## Data

My data source is the [gapminder](https://www.gapminder.org/) dataset.

```{r}
head(gapminder)
```


If this looks familiar to RMarkdown users, that‚Äôs because Quarto was built on lessons learned from developing RMarkdown. It includes all the features of RMarkdown and more.

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Learning objectives

Understand the principles of ‚Äútidy data‚Äù
Use tidyverse packages (dplyr and tidyr) to work with data in R.
Practice tracking our work in git

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
What is ‚Äútidy data‚Äù?
Lowndes and Horst say it so beautifully.

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text: The tidyverse

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
The ‚Äútidyverse‚Äù

‚ú® Common structure and syntax
‚ú® Emphasize user readability
‚ú® Friendly documentation
‚ú® Updates rapidly

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
The ‚Äútidyverse‚Äù

‚ÄºÔ∏è Extra installs over ‚Äúbase R‚Äù
‚ÄºÔ∏è Very different syntax than ‚Äúbase R‚Äù
‚ÄºÔ∏è Updates rapidly

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
The ‚Äútidyverse‚Äù

üß≠ Only install/load the functions/packages you need
üß≠ Be aware that others may be unfamiliar; comment your code well
üß≠ Keep track of your package versions
üß≠ Software developers, keep an eye on changes!

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Tidy data in R
Let‚Äôs install some packages:
install.packages("dplyr") # dataframe manipulation
install.packages("tidyr") # "reshaping" data
install.packages("palmerpenguins") # open teaching dataset

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
section: Coding time: Data types in R
text:
Coding time: Data types in R
Key points:

Major data types in R include characters, integers, double (numeric), Boolean (T/F), and factors.
Common tabular formats are data.frame or tibble
You can perform ‚Äúvectorized‚Äù operations on whole vectors (or columns) at once.
Missing data are handled as NAs.

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Coding time: dplyr
Core dplyr verbs:

select pulls columns
filter pulls rows based on values
mutate adds or modifies a column
group_by + summarize calculates group-wise summary statistics
*_join functions combine data frames based on matching columns

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
A note on pipes

Chain functions together into ‚Äúparagraphs‚Äù
%>%: older, included in dplyr (ultimately depends on magrittr)
|>: included in base R as of 4.1.0

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Coding time: tidyr
Key tidyr manipulations:

pivot_longer turns columns names into row values
pivot_wider creates new columns based on the values of a given field.







Note


Data should be as long as is reasonable (but not longer)!

title: Data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
section: Coding time: finding the right function
text:
Coding time: finding the right function

?tidyr::pivot_wider and index pages
More ways of getting help: see the Getting Help section!

text:

git add <your script name>

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Picking up from last week

Commit last week‚Äôs work to GitHub and push
Merge your work to main!
Create a new branch for today‚Äôs work and pull

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Data wrangling objectives:

Write a data wrangling script using the functions we covered last week

Use mutate to convert units of columns
Use summarize to calculate group-wise summary statistics
Use pivot_wider to create cross-tabs

Use ‚Äútidy selection‚Äù helpers to reduce repetition in this workflow!

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
What are functions in R?

We use pre-written functions constantly.
Automated ‚Äúrecipes‚Äù for executing code
Inputs (‚Äúarguments‚Äù) and outputs

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Why write our own functions?

Avoid repetition (+ mistakes)
Enhance portability + reproducibility

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Writing a function objectives

Convert our data wrangling script into a function
Break this function into smaller, human-readable functions
Make this function flexible to apply to other data

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
What are conditionals?

if and ifelse statements
Balance readability and flexibility in functions

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Conditionals in R

== for ‚Äúis equal to‚Äù
!= for ‚Äúnot equal to:
<, > for less than/greater than
<=, >= for less than or equal to/greater than or equal to
is.na() for is it NA?
%in% for, is this value in a vector of possibilities
‚Ä¶and more!

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Conditionals objectives

Add ifelse logic to our data wrangling function

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Finishing up

Commit your changes and push
Open a pull request.

text:
Homework

None, except for‚Ä¶

text:
Show and tell (Late October)

An opportunity to apply workshop skills to your own work.
You could apply different parts to different projects, or more integratively to one single project.
Optional, but encouraged!

title: Intermediate R: Advanced data wrangling, functions, and control flow
text:
Some inspirations

Turn the project folder for one of your current research project into a git/GitHub repo and/or R project
Modify an R script to use functions, conditionals, or best-practices for code formatting
Improve directory organization for project or your entire computer!

title: GitHub
text:
Review & Homework


If you turned an existing project into a git repo, how did it go?
Ways to create a git repo:

run git init from the command line inside of project directory
create a new RStudio project with ‚Äúuse git‚Äù checked
run usethis::use_git() in the R console in a RStudio project

title: GitHub
text:
Today‚Äôs goals

Practice using git with RStudio
Explore commit history
Learn how to tell git to ignore files
Put a local repo on GitHub
Use git push and git pull to synchronize with GitHub

title: GitHub
section: Working with git in RStudio (Live Coding)
text:
Working with git in RStudio (Live Coding)
The most common git commands can be used with the RStudio GUI.

title: GitHub
text:
Ignoring files

If you created an RStudio project with git enabled, you should have a top-level .gitignore
Use this file (or create one) to stop git/GitHub from tracking‚Ä¶

large files, especially if not plain text
files with sensitive data
unnecessary files (e.g.¬†.DS_Store)








Exercise


Modify .gitignore to exclude all files ending in .pdf from git tracking. Make a commit for this change

title: GitHub
text:
Sharing with GitHub








All contributors have a local copy of the repo.
You might also have a copy in multiple places (on multiple computers, on university HPC).
GitHub has a central repo that allows you to synchronize and merge work from multiple sources.
You can also access the repo through github.com web UI



Figure 2 from (Bryan 2018)

title: GitHub
text:
Connect With GitHub (Live Coding)

Set up your computer to ‚Äútalk‚Äù to GitHub with steps in git_sitrep()
Connect your local git repo to a remote GitHub repo with use_github()
Explore the GitHub interface

title: GitHub
section: Work With RStudio and GitHub (Live Coding)
text:
Work With RStudio and GitHub (Live Coding)

Push local changes to GitHub
Pull GitHub changes to local

Reporting bugs (or is it just me?)


Pay attention when opening an issue on GitHub‚Äîsometimes they are only supposed to be used for bug reports or feature requests and will direct you elsewhere for asking for help

title: Getting Help
text: Asking AI (not recommended)

title: Getting Help
text:
Beware of stochastic parrots1

LLMs don‚Äôt understand, but are good at mimicry
Use with care:

May be wrong
May be inconsistent




Tools like ChatGPT pose possible ethical issues

Plagiarism
Labor conditions
Inputs may be sent to parent companies



https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_parrot

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
section: Papers with open code are cited more
text:
Papers with open code are cited more







Figure 2: Predicted impacts of code-sharing on cumulative citations. Predicted values shown are for the mean Impact Factor (3.0) across the publications analyzed. Fully open = open code and open-access publication; fully closed = closed-access publication and no publicly available code. Predictions are based on estimated model coe cients (Table 2)


Figure 2 from Maitner et al. (2023)

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Getting credit for your code
Code is unfortunately not cited often, but you can help by making it easier to cite your code (in addition to making easy to reproduce!)

Provide a CITATION file on GitHub
Archive to get a digital object identifier (DOI)
Include DOI and/or citation in your paper‚Äôs Data/Code Availability Statement

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
CITATION.cff


Citation File Format are plain text files that are human- and machine-readable
Adding a CITATION.cff file to your repo‚Ä¶

Puts a ‚Äúcite this repository‚Äù button on GitHub
Helps code archive tools fill out metadata correctly when you archive your repo

Can include a ‚Äúpreferred citation‚Äù if you‚Äôd like people to cite a published paper in addition/instead
Create a CITATION.cff file with this helper

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Options for archiving










Service
Versioned DOIs?
Free?
GitHub integration?
Notes




Zenodo
Yes
Yes
Yes
Backed by CERN, built with code and data in mind


Dryad
Yes
No, but some publishers cover cost
No
Intended for data, not code. Partners with Zenodo


Figshare
Yes
Yes
Yes
Can‚Äôt choose your license


UA ReDATA
Yes
Yes (for UA researchers)
No
University of Arizona Libraries





More detailed comparisons here

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Reproducible computational environments
Congrats! Your code is reproducible! But what about ‚Ä¶.

in 3 years when an R package is updated with breaking changes?
on a different operating system with different versions of system libraries?

Capture the computational environment for ultimate reproducibility

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Reproducible Environments With renv

The renv package helps create reproducible environments by recording all the packages used in your project
Discovers and records required packages and their versions in renv.lock
Each project can have its own independent collection of R packages installed

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Using renv






Exercise


Install renv and activate it for a project with renv::init(). Inspect the files that were created.




To deactivate renv, run renv::deactivate(). To also remove all the files it created, run renv::deactivate(clean = TRUE) instead.

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Limitations of renv

Only tracks R packages 1
Can‚Äôt reproduce operating system or system libraries
Sometimes quite annoying to use (but it‚Äôs getting better!)

renv can also be set up to track Python dependencies

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Reproducible Everything with Docker
Docker containers‚Ä¶


Are isolated ‚Äúvirtual machines‚Äù
Run Linux regardless of the host machine OS
Can be built with specific versions of OS, system libraries, and R packages (using renv)
Can be downloaded and run from the command line

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
Making a Docker Container
A Dockerfile holds instructions on what to install and what code to run. Actually creating a Docker container is beyond the scope of this workshop, but you can learn how!
# Base image https://hub.docker.com/u/rocker/
FROM rocker/r-base:latest

## create directories
RUN mkdir -p /01_data
RUN mkdir -p /02_code
RUN mkdir -p /03_output

## copy files
COPY /02_code/install_packages.R /02_code/install_packages.R
COPY /02_code/myScript.R /02_code/myScript.R

## install R-packages
RUN Rscript /02_code/install_packages.R

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
section: Hold up, what is reproducibility again?
text:
Hold up, what is reproducibility again?
renv and Docker improve the numerical reproducibility, but add extra barriers to actually running and understanding the code. If you use these tools:

Provide instructions on how to run code in README
Provide instructions on how to troubleshoot or disable renv if it‚Äôs giving folks trouble
Provide code in a GitHub repo in addition to inside of a Docker container

title: Sharing Code & Getting Credit
text:
References






Reproduciblity & Data Science in R



Maitner, Brian, Paul Santos-Andrade, Luna Lei, George Barbosa, Brad Boyle, Matiss Castorena, Brian Enquist, et al. 2023. ‚ÄúCode Sharing Increases Citations, but Remains Uncommon.‚Äù https://doi.org/10.21203/rs.3.rs-3222221/v1.

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Review






Word Bank


repo | commit | remote | push | pull | add





A collection of files tracked by git
A snapshot of the state of a repository
git ___ is used to tell git to track a file
For example, a repo on GitHub
git ____ is used to synchronize changes on your computer with a remote

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Review
Did anyone add a repo to GitHub? What difficulties did you encounter?

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Collaborating with GitHub







A GitHub repo can be used to coordinate collaboration
If two people have permissions, both can push changes to the repo
Ask for a volunteer and give them permission to push to a repo


Figure 2 from (Bryan 2018)

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Example repo

Everyone practice cloning this example repo as a new RStudio project: https://github.com/cct-datascience/repro-workshop-demo 1
Need one volunteer to edit the README.md and practice commit + push

Read more about GitHub organizations

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Dealing with Conflicts

What happens when two people make conflicting edits to a file and push them?
Creates a merge conflict

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text: Ok, try git pull

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Merge, rebase, fast-forward??

These are alternative ways to deal with conflicts‚Äîwe won‚Äôt get into the details
For now, we recommend you stick with the ‚Äúmerge‚Äù option


Use:
git config pull.rebase false
Or, if you want to set this option for all future repos too
git config --global pull.rebase false

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Fixing a Merge Conflict


Resolve the conflict however you want (i.e.¬†keep one of the two sections)
Delete all lines with <<<<<<<, >>>>>>>, or =======
Save and commit


Let‚Äôs have a round of applause for our volunteer!

title: Collaborate With GitHub
section: Avoid merge conflicts by working on branches
text:
Avoid merge conflicts by working on branches
Each person works on a ‚Äúbranch‚Äù‚Äîan independent series of commits that can be merged back into the ‚Äúmain‚Äù branch.




gitGraph
   commit
   commit
   branch person_1
   commit
   commit
   commit
   checkout main
   branch person_2
   commit
   commit
   checkout main
   merge person_1
   merge person_2
   commit

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Working on a Branch

Make a new branch using RStudio‚Äôs Git pane (for this demo, use your name)
Commit changes and push to your branch
View changes on GitHub

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Pull Requests
A request to merge changes into the main branch

Need another volunteer to share screen and be guided through making a pull request
This time, everyone can follow along!

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Forks


What if you don‚Äôt have permission to push to a GitHub repo but you want to contribute?


Make a fork!














Since you can‚Äôt push to ‚Äúupstream‚Äù, you can make a connected copy on GitHub called a ‚Äúfork‚Äù

You can clone the fork and since you own it, you can push to it.
On GitHub, you can sync upstream changes with your fork and you can make pull requests to integrate changes on your fork into upstream.
That means you can contribute to anything! (as long as it is a public repo)

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
Collaborating with Forks
To contribute to a repo you don‚Äôt have push permission for:

Fork the repo to your own GitHub
Clone the fork to your local computer
Make commits (ideally on a branch)
Make a pull request to the upstream repo

Learn more, including handy usethis shortcuts: https://happygitwithr.com/fork-and-clone






Exercise


In pairs, practice this workflow to make a PR to our example repo

title: Collaborate With GitHub
text:
References






Reproduciblity & Data Science in R



Bryan, Jennifer. 2018. ‚ÄúExcuse Me, Do You Have a Moment to Talk about Version Control?‚Äù The American Statistician 72 (1): 2027. https://doi.org/10.1080/00031305.2017.1399928.

Learning objectives

Understand how iterating can improve your code
Iterate using for loops
Iterate using purrr

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
section: What do we mean by iteration?
text: What do we mean by iteration?

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
Iteration by hand
my_first_site <- read.csv("data_first.csv")
my_second_site <- read.csv("data_second.csv")
my_third_site <- read.csv("data_third.csv")
...

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
Why use code to iterate?

Less code: fewer bugs, easier to understand
Easier to apply to new situations
Faster to write, maybe faster to run

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
Iteration 3 (or more!) ways

For loops
Functions + purrr::map

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
Coding time: For loops

For loop
For loop with different indices

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
For loops: pros and cons

Pros

Simple to write and read

Cons

Can be slow
Still somewhat inefficient to write
Still somewhat fragile

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:
purrr::map

Family of functions to ‚Äúmap‚Äù a function over a series of items
(Often) faster and (often) easier to read and write than a for loop

title: Intermediate R II: Getting help, iteration, and mapping
text:

purrr

Identify a section of your code that could be made more efficient using a for loop or iterating using a function
Continue thinking about showcase projects.

title: Reproduciblity and Data Science in R
text: Welcome to the syllabus for the CCT Data Science fall workshop series: Reproducibility and Data Science in R. If you didn‚Äôt register for the course this year, sign up for our mailing list to be notified when enrollment opens for next year‚Äôs iteration and to be notified of our other monthly workshops.

title: Reproduciblity and Data Science in R
text:
Code of Conduct

Our group‚Äôs mission is to enable scientists. This means treating people with respect and responding in a polite and helpful way.
Our group is committed to ensuring a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of level of experience, gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, age, or religion.
Examples of unacceptable behavior by members, collaborators, and contributors include the use of sexual language or imagery, derogatory comments or personal attacks, trolling, public or private harassment, insults, or other unprofessional conduct.

Read our full code of conduct and please report any violations or concerns to the course instructors or to Kristina Riemer (kristinariemer@arizona.edu).

title: Reproduciblity and Data Science in R
text:
Helpful Reads
This workshop series doesn‚Äôt have anything like ‚Äúrequired reading‚Äù, but we think these books and websites are good companions.
Data analysis in R:

R for Data Science (2e)
Building reproducible analytical pipelines with R 

Best practices for reproducibility:

Good enough practices in scientific computing
Data organization in spreadsheets
A beginner‚Äôs guide to conducting reproducible research
The Turing Way: Guide for Reproducible Research

Version control:

Excuse me, do you have a moment to talk about version control?
Happy Git and GitHub for the useR

title: Using the Shell
text:
Understand the what and why of the shell
Use the shell to navigate your computer‚Äôs file system
Use R projects to simplify file system navigation
Know your options for finding help

title: Using the Shell
text:
Understand the what and why of the shell
Use the shell to navigate your computer‚Äôs file system
Use R projects to simplify file system navigation
Know your options for finding help

title: Using the Shell
text:
Lesson outline

Review of last week

What happened as you were trying to re-organize projects or R code? Victories? Stumbling blocks?

Slides: Intro to the shell

What is the shell?
What does the shell let us do?
Why would we want to learn how to use the shell?

Breakout rooms: Shell installation

Instructor notes include links to git installation for both Mac and Windows.
Split into 2 breakout rooms to install on different OS‚Äôs.

Break to all download shell-lesson-data

Link
Put it on your Desktop
Unzip using point-and-click

Live coding: Setup RStudio

Open RStudio
Tour panes: files and terminal
Set up terminal pane to use bash

Live coding: Navigating filesystems in files pane

Use file pane to navigate to shell-lesson-data

Live coding: Navigate to shell-lesson-data in Terminal

Identify the prompt and note that it is different in zsh (%)
pwd
cd
ls

Use ls flags to explain anatomy of a shell command
Show man ls to show flag options for the ls command


Live coding: Synchronizing file panes

Show ‚ÄúGo to current directory‚Äù to bring Terminal to files pane
Show ‚ÄúNew terminal here‚Äù to create a terminal in files pane
Show that Rstudio‚Äôs working directory is not automatically wherever either Terminal or the file pane is

Live coding: using Rprojects to simplify filesystems

Create an R project
Show that, upon opening, Terminal, getwd(), and file pane are all on the same page

Live coding: cp and move

Copy shell_lesson_data to the Rproject.
Tell them we need cp, then use cp --help to get the options
Repeat using ls to explore contents of shell_lesson_data and mirror files pane

Live coding/discussion: options for finding help

--help flag
man pages
Manual pages: ? in R, package websites
StackOverflow
ChatGPT

Homework for next session

Read https://peerj.com/preprints/3159/ git (Version control prep)
Create a diagram of your file system and note your most frequently used directories

title: Using the Shell
text:
Installation & materials

Slides
macOS git installation
Windows git installation (detailed step-by-step here)
Software Carpentry Unix Shell episode #1
Software Carpentry Unix Shell episode #2
Software Carpentry Unix Shell episode #3 (time permitting)

title: Intermediate R programming II
text: Learners will learn how to make their R code more reproducible using for loops and the apply family of functions.

title: Intermediate R programming II
text: Learners will learn how to make their R code more reproducible using for loops and the apply family of functions.

title: Intermediate R programming II
text:
Installation & materials

Slides
Data Carpentry for Biologists for loop lecture 
Data Carpentry for Biologists iteration without loops lecture? 


Review
Can share their plans for apply skills to their research. Lead optional discussion on when to use base R vs.¬†tidyverse packages/functions.


Modifications

For for loops lecture:

At ‚ÄúDo Tasks 3-4‚Ä¶‚Äù, do ‚ÄúBasic For Loop‚Äù exercises #2 & #3
Skip sections ‚ÄúLooping over multiple values‚Äù and ‚ÄúLooping with functions‚Äù
Stop at ‚ÄúLooping over files‚Äù due to zip download issues

For apply lecture:

Do ‚ÄúSize Estimates With Maximum‚Äù exercise
Do ‚ÄúSize Estimates Vectorized 2‚Äù exercise
Stop after first section in ‚ÄúOther apply functions (optional)‚Äù section

title: Intermediate R programming II
text:
Teaching notes

Create new R script for these materials. Put script into repro-DS-workshop repo
Emphasize using for loops using index or non-index methods. Index can be useful for reducing memory use and for storing results
If time, demonstrate combining if and for

title: Intermediate R programming II
text:
Homework
Identify a script from a research project that could benefit from a for loop, apply, conditional, or function.

title: Collaborating with GitHub
text: Learners will fork and clone a repository on GitHub and use branches to open pull requests.

title: Collaborating with GitHub
text: Learners will fork and clone a repository on GitHub and use branches to open pull requests.

title: Collaborating with GitHub
text:
Lesson Outline

Review Homework:

Anyone put a repo on GitHub? Any difficulties encountered?

Live Coding: Collaborating with GitHub

Share a repo with everyone & have everyone clone w/ RStudio
Ask 1 (one) volunteer to make a change and practice commit + push
Instructor makes commit + push, volunteer pulls

Live Coding: Merge conflict

Instructor makes commit to README and pushes to GitHub
Volunteer makes commit to the same line of README and pushes without pulling first
Should error for volunteer

Slides: Resolving merge conflict
Live Coding: Resolve merge conflict

Try following the hints in the error and pull
New error about divergent branches
Then have everyone set git config pull.rebase false

Working on branches (slides)
Live Coding:

Make a branch with your name in RStudio
Add your name to README and commit
Switch between branches and see the file change in RStudio AND in File Explorer / Finder
Push & see branches on GitHub

Pull Requests (slides)
Live Coding:

Have everyone make a PR to add their name to the README
Demo merging one or two & ask volunteer to resolve any merge conflicts

Forks (slides)

Discuss when you would work on a branch of a fork vs.¬†working in a branch but on the same repo

Live Coding:

Have students create a fork of a second example repo and clone their fork
In pairs, have them practice making a branch, making changes, commit + push, and make a PR on GitHub

Homework:

Maybe try cloning a repo that you don‚Äôt have permission to push to to see what happens
Try using usethis::pr_finish() on a branch that was already merged on GitHub and take note of what it does

title: Getting Credit For Your Hard Work
text: Learn the wrap-up steps to publish/archive a research compendium with a DOI. Understand reproducible computational environment. Learn renv and discuss Docker (concept).

title: Getting Credit For Your Hard Work
text: Learn the wrap-up steps to publish/archive a research compendium with a DOI. Understand reproducible computational environment. Learn renv and discuss Docker (concept).

title: Getting Credit For Your Hard Work
text:
Lesson Outline

Why share code?

Facilitate discussion
Show figure from Maitner et al. (2023)
Higher citations
To ‚Äúpay it forward‚Äù to other researchers
To demonstrate your skills
To facilitate error correction

Getting credit for code

Code is not cited often, but partly because it‚Äôs not made easy to cite

CITATION.cff

Show CITATION.cff files for this repo and maybe one for a research compendium
Show ‚Äúcite this‚Äù button on GitHub
Maybe mention cffr::cff_validate()

Archiving

Most participants probably won‚Äôt be ready to follow along with their own repos, but we will be there to help when they are ready
Demo archiving a repo with Zenodo using this repo
Add DOI badge to readme
Update CITATION.cff with DOI

renv

Discuss why
Ask students to activate renv for a project and inspect files it creates
Explain how renv works, especially renv::restore() , renv::status() , and renv::snapshot()
Demo activating renv for this repo and make a second release to demo Zenodo versioning

Docker (if time)

Conceptual overview of what it is
Discuss how tools like renv and Docker both help and hinder reproducibility

title: Getting Credit For Your Hard Work
text:
Homework

Prep for showcase session

title: Getting help
text: Slides

title: Getting help
text:
Objectives

Know your options for finding help
Understand how to create a minimal reproducible example to get better help

title: Getting help
section: Live coding/discussion: options for finding help
text:
Live coding/discussion: options for finding help

--help flag
man pages
? in R
Package websites (found with google or through CRAN page)

These often are the same material as help files + vignettes, but easier to read and examples are rendered on web

StackOverflow

People aren‚Äôt always the friendliest, but making a reprex helps you get good answers

Minimal reproducible examples with reprex

Demo RStudio addin

ChatGPT

Not recommended for beginners!
Sometimes (~50% by some estimates) gives the wrong answer, difficult to spot mistakes if you‚Äôre a beginner

title: Developing Code on Github
text: Learners will share their local repository on GitHub and learn how to sync some files while ignoring others systematically. Learners will practice developing new code on branches.

title: Developing Code on Github
text: Learners will share their local repository on GitHub and learn how to sync some files while ignoring others systematically. Learners will practice developing new code on branches.

title: Developing Code on Github
text:
Lesson Outline

Review:

Ways of creating a git repo and how to know if it worked
(live coding) turn demo project from lesson 1 into a git repo with usethis::use_git()

Live Coding: working with git in RStudio

Demo add commit cycle with git pane AND git menu

Live Coding: .gitignore

Explore .gitignore created by RStudio
Software Carpentry .gitignore lesson
Discuss what files to .gitignore: what is ‚Äúnon-diffable‚Äù?
Modify and make a commit

What is GitHub and why use it? (slides)
Live Coding: GitHub setup

Go through checklist of usethis::git_sitrep() with student sharing screen
Don‚Äôt have student share screen with PAT generation! Switch to your screen!

Live Coding: Putting your code on GitHub

Local first: usethis::use_github()
GitHub first: create new repo on GitHub and create new R Studio project from version control
Other ways are possible, but we‚Äôre not going to cover them this lesson (unless someone has issues)

Live Coding: Push and Pull

Make changes in RStudio, push
Make changes on GitHub, pull
Have Renata make changes, push, then pull

Next time: How to work together on GitHub more safely
Homework: Put a personal repository on GitHub.

title: Developing Code on Github
text:
Installation & materials

Slides
Software Carpentry Version Control with Git episode #6
GitHub authentication with PAT using Jenny Bryan‚Äôs Git book chapter 9 (follow usethis::git_sitrep())
Software Carpentry Version Control with Git episode #7
Software Carpentry branching add-on


Review
If anyone turned a folder into a repository, share how that went.

title: Developing Code on Github
text:
Teaching notes

Practice another add-commit cycle after creating the .gitignore
Introduce the add-commit-push cycle

title: Developing Code on Github
text:
Homework
Connect a personal repository to GitHub. Practice usethis::use_git() and usethis::use_github().

title: Intermediate R programming I
text:
Understand the utility of writing your own functions and managing control flow.
Write functions and if/else statements to improve code readability and reusability
Create pull requests updating a git repo with new code.

title: Intermediate R programming I
text:
Understand the utility of writing your own functions and managing control flow.
Write functions and if/else statements to improve code readability and reusability
Create pull requests updating a git repo with new code.

title: Intermediate R programming I
text:
Lesson outline

Review from last session
Warm-up

Update working branch from upstream

Slides/lecture: Why write functions?

Base on DC semester biology lesson
Understandable and reusable code

Human-understandable chunks
Designed to be reused


Live-coding: functions

Function basics from DC semester lesson
Create new R script for functions content, and another new R script for control flow (ifelse and for loops) content. Put both scripts into repro-DS-workshop repo
Discuss ordering of an R script

Slides/lecture: control flow

Examples of use of if/else statements (find some real-world examples)
DC semester on conditionals
Review conditional logic
Conditionals outside functions
Conditionals inside functions

Live-coding: practice commit + PR
Discussion: application to own work + showcase
Homework:

Create a plan for applying these skills to their own research projects. Can apply different parts to different projects, or more integratively to one single project. Some possibilities:

Turn the project folder for one of your current research project into a git/GitHub repo and/or R project
Modify an R script to use functions, if/for loops, or format code according to best practices
Improve file and folder organization for project or your entire computer!

Find a section of own code to turn into a function

title: Intermediate R programming I
text:
Installation & materials

Slides
Data Carpentry for Biologists functions lecture
Data Carpentry for Biologists conditionals lecture

title: Intermediate R programming I
text:
Notes from before

Review
Ask to share cleaning up of example script, their own script, or their research project folder from lesson 5.


Modifications

For functions lecture, had them do only the ‚ÄúUse and Modify‚Äù exercise
From conditionals lecture, only did ‚Äúif statements‚Äù section
From latter, only did ‚ÄúBasic If Statements‚Äù #2 exercise
Added on brief explanation of ifelse, using the example of ifelse(length == 5, "correct", "incorrect")
Mention case_when from dplyr for more complicated if & else steps



Teaching notes

Before doing functions and conditions, demonstrate updating local cct-organization repo from upstream after adding a commit to the upstream
Create new R script for functions content, and another new R script for control flow (ifelse and for loops) content. Put both scripts into repro-DS-workshop repo
Mention functions are often used with for loops or apply statements
After functions, mention consistent order of sections in scripts; example is libraries, read in data, functions, executing functions
Include real world examples of if and ifelse statements to motivate their use, especially for checking if files already exist
Demonstrate making a new branch and opening up a pull request in their repro-DS-workshop repo at the end of each set of material; can merge pull request



Homework
Create a plan for applying these skills to their own research projects. Can apply different parts to different projects, or more integratively to one single project. Some possibilities:

Turn the project folder for one of your current research project into a git/GitHub repo and/or R project
Modify an R script to use functions, if/for loops, or format code according to best practices
Improve file and folder organization for project or your entire computer!

title: Data manipulation
text:
Use git branches in the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù
Reproducibly clean, summarize, and organize dataframes using tidyverse packages
Understand how R stores different data types (data frames, vector types, missing data)
Know what the tidyverse is, how it differs from base R, and the philosophy behind using it here.
Use the pipe to chain operations together
Use dplyr functions to subset data (select, filter; logic and select fxns including where, ==, %in%, !) and manipulate data (mutate; lubridate; split-apply-combine)
Use tidyr functions to reshape data (pivot_wider and pivot_longer)

title: Data manipulation
text:
Use git branches in the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù
Reproducibly clean, summarize, and organize dataframes using tidyverse packages
Understand how R stores different data types (data frames, vector types, missing data)
Know what the tidyverse is, how it differs from base R, and the philosophy behind using it here.
Use the pipe to chain operations together
Use dplyr functions to subset data (select, filter; logic and select fxns including where, ==, %in%, !) and manipulate data (mutate; lubridate; split-apply-combine)
Use tidyr functions to reshape data (pivot_wider and pivot_longer)

title: Data manipulation
text:
Lesson outline

Review from last week
Warm-up: create a branch for today‚Äôs work
Slides/discussion: using R for reproducible data analysis

Why use R?
What is the tidyverse and why use it?
Install dplyr and tidyr

Live coding: How R thinks about data

Data carpentry R ecology revamp episode #2
Data frames
Vectors and data types
Missing data

Live coding: dplyr and tidyr

Data carpentry R ecology revamp episode #3
Recent DC + R lesson
Chaining lines together with the pipe

%>%, |>

Subsetting and filtering data

incl.¬†selection and pick https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/dplyr_tidy_select.html

Adding columns
Split-apply-combine
Reshaping

Live coding: advanced tidyverse topics

Options: across; dates; advanced joins; others?

Live coding/discussion: getting help

reprex

Live coding: practice modify-add-commit cycle
Homework: None

title: Documentation and Literate Programming
text: Understand how to write a README.md using markdown basics and introduce the concept of literate programming with Quarto.

title: Documentation and Literate Programming
text: Understand how to write a README.md using markdown basics and introduce the concept of literate programming with Quarto.

title: Documentation and Literate Programming
text:
Lesson Outline

What goes in a README?

Project summary
Project status (in progress, archived, just an idea?)
How to give credit
Structure of repo (what files do what?)
How to reproduce results

Markdown & formatting a README.md

Markdown is a markup language: plain text ‚Äì> formatted text
Widely used (GitHub, websites, Slack, etc.)
Show markdown cheat sheet
Spaces matter, and don‚Äôt matter at the same time. Err on the side of too much space between elements

Exercise: Spend a few minutes editing your README, commit, push to GitHub and observe
Quarto: an open-source scientific and technical publishing system

Allows combining markdown, code, and code output (tables, plots, etc)
Wide variety of outputs: html, pdf, word, and more
Use cases:

Notebook
Share results with collaborators
Presentations
Reproducible manuscripts


How does it work?

qmd -> knitr -> md -> pandoc -> word, pdf, html, etc.

Anatomy of a .Qmd

Look familiar if you‚Äôve used RMarkdown
YAML header has metadata and settings
Markdown body
Code chunks with R, Python, Julia, or other code

Create .Qmd and play
Demo rendering in different formats
Demo visual editor

Switch back and forth
Callouts

Code chunk options

Demo some common ones like label, echo: false, fig-cap

Citations and cross-refs
Tease journal articles (check out AGU format example https://quarto-journals.github.io/agu/)
Point students toward tutorial and full documentation

title: Project Management and Coding Best Practices
text: Learners will learn about and practice managing their projects using file structure and RStudio projects, and about current best practices and style guides for R coding.

title: Project Management and Coding Best Practices
text: Learners will learn about and practice managing their projects using file structure and RStudio projects, and about current best practices and style guides for R coding.

title: Project Management and Coding Best Practices
text:
Lesson Outline

Introductions
Discuss reproducibility
Give tour of course website & syllabus

Point out code of conduct

Screen setup
Don‚Äôt save or load .RData!
Discuss general best practices for research compendia (use Carpentry lesson)

All files needed for a project in the same folder (ideally)
Organize data, code, and outputs into different folders at a minimum
Never edit raw data
Include documentation on what each file is/does in a README

Live Coding: create an R project and add gapminder data to it

Show file pane & connect to Windows Explorer / Finder
Show how to make a file read-only
Demo closing, opening, and switching projects

Live Coding: R code best practices

Create 01-wrangle-data.R in R/
Header comment
Don‚Äôt use setwd()‚Äînot needed with .Rproj. Use relative paths!
Keyboard shortcut for adding sections + outline view and navigator at bottom of script panel
Load packages at top of script, even when not used until later
Restart R and run from top often
Code styling with RStudio (ctl + shift + A)
How to break up code (e.g.¬†save output of 01-wrangle-data.R into data_clean/, then read that in later)

Homework:

Apply one or more of the organizing principles of a research compendium to an existing research project.

title: Project Management and Coding Best Practices
text:
Installation & materials

Slides
Software Carpentry Introduction to R and RStudio episode
Software Carpentry Project Management with RStudio episode
Software Carpentry Best Practices for Writing R Code
https://r4ds.hadley.nz/workflow-style

title: Version control with git
text:
Understand the concept and motivation of version control
Set up git on their machine (email address linked to their GH account; --global config)
Understand that repos == folders =can= .Rproj.
Initialize a git repo associated with an RStudio project called pilot-analyses.
Understand the modify-add-commit progression. Apply this by making modifications to some R code and then committing it to the pilot-analyses repo (git commands: status, log, diff, add, commit)
Use .gitignore to selectively exclude files from git.

title: Version control with git
text:
Understand the concept and motivation of version control
Set up git on their machine (email address linked to their GH account; --global config)
Understand that repos == folders =can= .Rproj.
Initialize a git repo associated with an RStudio project called pilot-analyses.
Understand the modify-add-commit progression. Apply this by making modifications to some R code and then committing it to the pilot-analyses repo (git commands: status, log, diff, add, commit)
Use .gitignore to selectively exclude files from git.

title: Version control with git
text:
Lesson outline

Review of last week

Ask folks to share the diagram of their file system
Warm-up with review question from the slide deck

Slides/lecture: Intro to version control with git

What is version control?
Why should I learn this? When will I need it?

Live coding: git config

SW Carpentry Git lesson 2 https://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/02-setup
Setting up git using git config

Make sure participants use their GH email/intended GH email
git verb options
git config --global core.editor "vim"
git verb --help


Live coding: git init

SW Carpentry Git lesson 3 https://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/03-create.html
Introduce the concept of a repository
Go over 3 ways to init a git repo and when to use each
Break to all create a project + repo called pilot-analyses

Live coding: git status

Use git status to check that git init worked
Talk about git status as a bridge to tracking changes.

Live coding: Tracking changes

SW Carpentry Git lesson 4 https://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/04-changes
Visualize in slides
Create a blank R file (using RStudio point and click)
Make comments/pseudocode changes.
git status
Go through git add/commit cycle
Repeat with additional changes, use git diff
Repeat with multiple files
Undo saved changes to a file using git restore
Use git reset HEAD~ to undo the git add and git commit commands

Live coding: .gitignore

SW Carpentry Git lesson 6https://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/06-ignore
.gitignore:

DS_Store
Create a file and then ignore it.


(Time permitting): SW Carpentry Git lesson 5

https://swcarpentry.github.io/git-novice/05-history
Navigating git history

Homework:

Create a GitHub account if you don‚Äôt have one.
(Optional) identify an existing folder and turn it into a repository.
